content: This PR is ready for review. The manifold version is on its way.
I remember thinking the same thing in 1990 when I saw this trick in manifolds class!
When learning real analysis, I could not get to grips with the fact that there could be smooth, non-constant, compactly supported functions. I am glad that Lean is now past this stage as well!
I fled into algebraic geometry for the same reason (-;
Another example that was really hard for me to grasp was the existence of nowhere differentiable, continuous functions. Is this already in mathlib?
No, but it'd be great to have. The Takagi construction is my favourite.
Maybe a project for one of our undergraduate analysts ...?
Oh, unless we have the Baire category construction?
Sounds like a great idea! I remember that I really learned a lot by thinking of these examples.
In a similar spirit, Peano curves could also be fun!
